```
def write_version(filename=os.path.join(*[settings.AIRFLOW_HOME,
                                          'airflow',
                                          'git_version'])):
    text = "{}".format(git_version(version))
    with open(filename, 'w') as a:
        a.write(text)

```

comments.body: ?? This is needed for docs? I would have though mock is just used in tests/, and i’m Surprised it’s needed here?
Good point. @tedmiston Any idea?

I did some digging and looks like we use it here:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/acca61c602e341da06ebee2eca3a26f4e7400238/docs/conf.py#L16

This is used for mocking import of various modules:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/docs/conf.py#L18-L31


Reference: http://blog.rtwilson.com/how-to-make-your-sphinx-documentation-compile-with-readthedocs-when-youre-using-numpy-and-scipy/
@Fokko What Kaxil found is consistent with what I saw as well.  There's a bit more info on it in (1) in my comment here https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3703#issuecomment-410836135.
Just learned something, thanks @tedmiston !
Could you add `[AIRFLOW-3147]` in to your commit message too please?
There's a 1.3.6 out
Done.
Can we use a version range instead of pinning to an exact version?

The problem is that those libraries are pretty unstable and relying on automated upgrade for future versions is pretty bad idea - last time when @DariuszAniszewski  upgraded 0.30.0 (I think) -> 0.31.0 it actually broke the operator and some fixes had to be made (and we cannot really rely on future versions to not break anything). Other dependencies also made breaking changes quite recently when they automatically upgraded (infamous flask-appbuilder for example). There is a whole discussion on keeping fixed vs. upper-open version number on the devlist (I am involved but had no time to take a closer look at this yet). I think for now - until general approach is implemented, I think it's safer to keep it fixed.
n00b qq: what does ~= mean?
got it(https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/): ```~=: Compatible release clause```

It means it will select the latest version of the package, greater or equal to 0.6.10, but still in the 0.6.* version, so it won't download 0.7.0 for example. It ensures you will get security fixes but keep backward-compatibility, if the package maintainer respects the semantic versioning (which states that breaking changes should occur only in major versions).

Or, as said by PEP 440:

> For a given release identifier V.N , the compatible release clause is approximately equivalent to the pair of comparison clauses:
> 
> \>= V.N, == V.*
`google-cloud-translate>=1.3.3` before `google-cloud-vision>=0.35.2` for alphabetical?
Good catch
Fixed.
Not sure that `*.tgz` should be in here - that isn't a file that the build/setup.py produces is it? (as those would live under build/ or dist/)

comments.body: Nice, thanks!
My that's quite the version specificiation! Where did it come from?

I've based it on the master branch of the Flask-OAuthlib git repository:

https://github.com/lepture/flask-oauthlib/blob/9e6f152a5bb360e7496210da21561c3e6d41b0e1/setup.py#L44-L47

There were 2 commits to pin these versions:

https://github.com/lepture/flask-oauthlib/commit/bd06c64fec62e4f37aaed769d4f5156b30405e26
https://github.com/lepture/flask-oauthlib/commit/1379c6b27c17e3aac5ea071f12aca59f02c924b6

Similar to https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/5036, we can unpin these once a new release of Flask-OAuthlib is released which includes the above changes.
Is it an Apache approved library?
BSD, which is Cat-A http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-a
is this version tested on Travis CI?

Good point @mik-laj:


For Flake8 [runs against 3.6.7](https://travis-ci.org/apache/airflow/jobs/544402855#L199-L200), by using the system's python binary:
```
python --version
Python 3.6.7
```

For the actual tests, it runs [runs against 3.5](https://travis-ci.org/apache/airflow/jobs/544588510#L1715) provided by tox.

comments.body: I don't see blinker used anywhere?
Flask has a signals system that the SDK uses to hook into Flask apps. The signalling system requires blinker. It's an optional dependency of Flask.
Maybe we should add similar warning in the airflow script? Then it will be printed every time you run any cli command. It's a bit spammy, but maybe it's the best way to warn users.
Hmmm maybe -- that is probably a bit _too_ spammy

Maybe just once after installation or at some specific operations - for example when running webserver or scheduler ? That might be less spammy but still run often by the users/devops maintaining Airflow.

Added it to webserver, scheduler, version, upgradedb, initdb, and resetdb commands

I also re-used coloring code from pip if it's available.
The issue is I think that clous-spanner 1.10.0 now needs https://pypi.org/project/google-cloud-iam/#history 0.2.0 but didn't list that as a dep.
Yeah. Let's fix it for now to unblock master merges and we will have a separate work on aligning all gcp dependencies.

I was slightly wrong, but its related to this:

```
google-cloud-container 0.3.0 has requirement grpc-google-iam-v1<0.13dev,>=0.12.3, but you'll have grpc-google-iam-v1 0.11.4 which is incompatible.
google-cloud-spanner 1.10.0 has requirement grpc-google-iam-v1<0.13dev,>=0.12.3, but you'll have grpc-google-iam-v1 0.11.4 which is incompatible.
```

> License: GNU General Public License v2 (GPLv2) (GPL version 2)

I can't remember what the outcome was on this for other devel only changes. @mik-laj Do you remember?

(Somewhat annoyingly isort itself is MIT)

Discussion about flake-import-order in Airflow is available here:
https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/4892#issuecomment-472369397
I think it should be moved to devel - otherwise we might have similar problems like the #6009

This will make it harder to use this command on a cloud composer. This does not install `devel` dependencies. 

After that, it seems to me that you haven't checked what this library is.  This is not graphviz that you know from the console interface (https://www.graphviz.org/).  This is not a dot program and all its friends. This is just a library that makes it easy to build dot documents. To use this change you still need to have graphviz installed on your system. However, only if you want to save the result to a file or display on the console.

Please look at setup.py: https://github.com/xflr6/graphviz/blob/master/setup.py
This is not a problematic library. It has no dependencies.
Agreee. Merged.

Correct @feluelle -> @nuclearpinguin, otherwise nose will still be there in the image.
